snippet: Nuance doesn’t do well on cable, so a topic as fraught as race often ends up being covered in cartoonish ways during signal events like the death of Trayvon Martin.
abstract: David Carr The Media Equation column examines episode of MSNBC's television program All In, during which Chris Hayes and Gawker writer Cord Jefferson parodied race discussions indicative of cables news; asserts that nuance does not play well on cable, and as a result, topics as fraught as race often end up being covered in cartoonish ways during signal events like the death of Trayvon Martin.
lead_paragraph: Nuance doesn’t do well on cable, so a topic as fraught as race often ends up being covered in cartoonish ways during signal events like the death of Trayvon Martin.

headline.print_headline: Parodying Cable News With a Talk About Race
headline.main: Parodying Cable News With a Talk About Race
